This game's campaign wasn't for me. While I loved doing the demolition stuff (Why I bought the game), I found the exploration of the levels to be kind of boring and the idea of spending long chunks of time fighting the in-game physics to make a route that may or may not work to pull off heists within under a minute gave me a headache rather than excitement.  I also think the game would way more enjoyable with a co-op mode, but that would take a lot of rework with the mechanics of heists themselves.  I blame myself for not researching the game all that much before buying because if I'd known about the heists and their conditions and requirements for completion, I would have likely skipped out on buying the game.  But you know what?  I *respect* the campaign for what it does, I *respect* the people who find it fun, and I respect the developer for crafting what was clearly a game mode for people who love heists and doing the planning.

That said, the sandbox, modding tools/support, and fun you can have with blowing stuff up or smashing it all down with your sledgehammer make this game worth recommending even though I will not be likely coming back to it.

I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't.  The concept of having a complete voxel world you can tear apart is fantastic and THAT part of the game, along with the mechanics and physics, is top-notch.  But the game isn't about tearing down a voxel world; it's about completing missions for various NPCs. This honestly isn't a bad thing, either. 

Where the game goes south is in the handling of those missions. You are given a set of increasingly complex tasks which requires you to set everything up absolutely perfectly--which requires many, many attempts to get it just right--and then given 60 seconds to complete the overall task or heist.  Instead of letting you figure out different ways to fully complete a task, there is literally ONE way to complete it and it has to be done in that 60 second time frame.  It's not fun at all and IMHO, that ruins the game. 

After a few hours, I simply lost interest in wasting hours upon hours trying to blow up a wall just right so I could "hopefully" dangle a safe out a window without tripping an alarm.

And that's too bad.  Could have been stellar.

I will likely keep playing the game (sunk cost fallacy) and maybe even be Stockholm syndromed into liking it. But, so far, I am really not feeling it. The game has beautiful voxel graphics and crazy destructibility. The tools, like a blowtorch that lets you sever metal, and vehicle driving is very fun, and the missions where you simply have to destroy stuff are great.

Why the problem, then? Well, after a few missions, everyone amps up security on their stuff, and the game ceases to become about any sort of demolition and becomes a timed heist puzzle game. it's essentially a bait and switch. This alone isn't necessarily bad, I mean, I loved Monaco: What's Yours is Mine, and it was one of my favorite games. But, the alarms simply don't make any logical sense whatsoever. Somehow, the targets slap a museum tier motion sensor solely on the things you have to steal that can't be turned off by any means, as there is no power box for them to find and destroy. Whereas most heist scenarios feature stuff like distracting guards, hacking computers, shutting off power, or misdirection, this game simply uses the invincible alarm as an excuse to make the game harder. Conveniently, these geniuses forgot to put security on anything BESIDES precisely what you are trying to steal.

As a result, most of the demolition you are able to do doesn't matter in the slightest and is purely for messing around. You can still win just by making a few small holes in walls and proper placement of cars and boats. "Teardown" is something of a misnomer.

Adding to the annoyance is that demolition is finicky. Stuff seems to be equally susceptible to destruction no matter the material, so cars crumble like balsa wood when they hit anything and construction vehicles that ought to be nigh-indestructible somehow come apart at the seams. At least at first, you can only attach things with planks that come apart at the slightest bump. This makes it easy to fail complex missions for ridiculous reasons. While it also makes for humorous moments, it doesn't conform to any logic, and in a game that is not just about sandbox goofiness but precision heists, it needs to work when you actually want it to work.  The game urges you to quicksave at every opportunity, probably because it knows it just randomly breaks, but that isn't really a substitute for working properly.

This was a great idea for a game with horrible execution. The story missions consist of grabbing some item, then making it out of the map before time expires. Why build a game based on destruction if the only thing you need to destruct is a few walls to steal items and get away in a minute or two?? Yay! right? NOPE - this giant bulldozer gets easily high centered running over small items, it even got stuck trying to run over a handful of voxels, and once it gets high centered it's done. Also, the machine tips over like [b]crazy[/b] even trying to make a turn or climbing a curb, making them completely useless. When you can use the machinery without getting high centered or tipping, the dozer goes through only a handful of walls or moves a car 50 feet before the dozers bucket is [b]completely destroyed and useless. WTF??[/b] - is it made of plastic!?! Why build this whole destructible environment and not let us do anything. Plus the physics are waaay out of whack, one example being the machinery issues I just said, another example -  I took out almost the whole first floor of a brick tower's walls, there were 3 bricks connecting the tower to the ground, and the tower magically stood there without collapsing. AND, when taking out those bricks, the brick tower fell 10 feet to the floor and stayed completely upright intact. I just don't understand how this game has so many positive reviews. ::shrug:: idk, maybe I'm somehow playing the game wrong somehow... I'm extremely disappointed in this game.

First, requires Steam to run. That right there earns any game a thumbs down with me. Now on to the games problems.
Boring! The entire campaign is just doing the same thing over and over again on the same maps over and over again. Only the location of the objects you need to collect changes. They call them heist missions but it's really just grabbing a number of items and getting to your vehicle in 60 seconds before the alarm sounds. So the entire game play is just setting up a scenario where you can get from point A to point B to point C, etc... before time runs out. Which usually just means knocking a hole in a wall and placing a vehicle where you can get to it quickly. Once you've done this once or twice it begins to feel very repetitive. Especially when it's on a map you've already done this on several times. There is just no variety to the missions.
The racing DLC is not much better as the AI drivers are atrocious. They don't acknowledge either you or the other AI drivers. So they constantly try to drive through you and the other AI as if you are not there. So you are constantly being bashing into by the AI. Many times they will literally be stuck to you as they try and occupy the same lane as you. So you will start races over and over and over and over and over and over and over again. And that is not nearly enough 'overs' to come close to describing the extent of the issue. And the AI is so bad that the only way to they could make it a challenge is to put you in a slower car then the AI. And it suffers from an issue seen in many racing games with bad AI. I will likely keep playing the game (sunk cost fallacy) and maybe even be Stockholm syndromed into liking it. But, so far, I am really not feeling it. The game has beautiful voxel graphics and crazy destructibility. The tools, like a blowtorch that lets you sever metal, and vehicle driving is very fun, and the missions where you simply have to destroy stuff are great.

Why the problem, then? Well, after a few missions, everyone amps up security on their stuff, and the game ceases to become about any sort of demolition and becomes a timed heist puzzle game. it's essentially a bait and switch. This alone isn't necessarily bad, I mean, I loved Monaco: What's Yours is Mine, and it was one of my favorite games. But, the alarms simply don't make any logical sense whatsoever. Somehow, the targets slap a museum tier motion sensor solely on the things you have to steal that can't be turned off by any means, as there is no power box for them to find and destroy. Whereas most heist scenarios feature stuff like distracting guards, hacking computers, shutting off power, or misdirection, this game simply uses the invincible alarm as an excuse to make the game harder. Conveniently, these geniuses forgot to put security on anything BESIDES precisely what you are trying to steal.

As a result, most of the demolition you are able to do doesn't matter in the slightest and is purely for messing around. You can still win just by making a few small holes in walls and proper placement of cars and boats. "Teardown" is something of a misnomer.

Adding to the annoyance is that demolition is finicky. Stuff seems to be equally susceptible to destruction no matter the material, so cars crumble like balsa wood when they hit anything and construction vehicles that ought to be nigh-indestructible somehow come apart at the seams. At least at first, you can only attach things with planks that come apart at the slightest bump. This makes it easy to fail complex missions for ridiculous reasons. While it also makes for humorous moments, it doesn't conform to any logic, and in a game that is not just about sandbox goofiness but precision heists, it needs to work when you actually want it to work.  The game urges you to quicksave at every opportunity, probably because it knows it just randomly breaks, but that isn't really a substitute for working properly.
